data.title: Dennett’s prime-mammal objection to the consequence argument
data.abstract: The Consequence Argument is the classic argument for the incompatibility of determinism and our ability to do otherwise. Daniel C. Dennett objects that the Consequence Argument suffers from the same error as a clearly unconvincing argument that there are no mammals. In this paper, I argue that these arguments do not suffer from the same error. The argument that there are no mammals is unconvincing as it takes the form of a sorites, whereas the Consequence Argument does not. Accordingly, Dennett's objection misses its mark.
data.keywords: Daniel C. Dennett, determinism, free will, sorites paradox, the Basic Argument, the Consequence Argument
